item.title: Variable Assignment
item.description: R Python C++ Rcpp R var_R <- 1 var_R ## [1] 1 Python var_PY = 1 print(var_PY) ## 1 C++ #include <iostream> int main() { int var_CPP = 1; std::cout << var_CPP; return 0; } ## 1 Rcpp #include <Rcpp.h> // R to/from C++ interface // [[Rcpp::export]] int RCPP_function() { int var_RCPP = 1; return var_RCPP; } RCPP_function() # access the C++ function from R like any other function ## [1] 1

item.title: reticulate: Taking the Dragon for a Test Ride
Thoughts on Teaching R and Yet Another Tidyverse Intro
item.description:
Context Reflection Resources Up Front tibble %>% “Tidy” Data select() columns filter() Rows mutate() Columns arrange() Rows group_by() for Grouped Data summarize() Image credit to R Memes for Statistical Fiends
Considering this is a blog post, I’m going to get all bloggy here before jumping into the code. Context I recently had the opportunity to teach some R coding to colleagues and classmates in a series of workshops.

item.title: GDELT, Missiles, and Image Collection
item.description: -- -- The Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone, or GDELT, is “a realtime network diagram and database of global human society for open research”. The potential for a firehose stream of global data has tantalizing possibilities for research, but concrete examples of work beyond simple evaluations of the database’s capabilities are notably absent… See also: My hasty walkthrough from November 2017, Evaluating GDELT: Syrian Conflict Let’s see how well we can scoop up a set of ballistic missile images using a combination of packages:
